sentences.sentence: Emissions No one can do much about climate change if they are trapped in poverty.

Australia can help to fix both problems.Australia's climate debate is divorced from the realities of the developing world.There is a great risk that elite opinion in rich Western countries becomes fossilised into fossil fuel absolutism.

Expressing any scepticism about a blanket approach to climate action represents net zero for one's social standing.And nowhere is this elitism more apparent than among the cabal of wealthy financiers who have emerged as the key backers of independent climate-activist political candidates set to run in the next federal election.But it's unjust for rich countries to embrace an anti-fossil-fuel triumphalism at the cost of the development and climate resilience of the poor.
This has lately been underlined as energy prices soar in India and China, as coal shortages bite.
"A country like India has huge power needs," says A. K. Saxena of the Energy and Resources Institute of India, a think tank focused on sustainable transition.
"Climate change action must be balanced with poverty reduction, social cohesion and employment concerns.
"Coal is the default energy choice for the poor, and that is unlikely to change for decades.
India and China are projected to still be meeting almost 40 per cent of their energy needs through coal in 2040.

Between them they account for more than a third of the world's carbon emissions, a share that will continue to grow.In relative terms, China has reduced the share of coal in its energy mix steadily since 2007.
In non-OECD states excluding China, consumption rose by 2.7 per cent a year.

Countries outside the OECD accounted for 80 per cent of the worldwide coal consumption in 2019, according to BP's annual energy report.The best contribution Australia can make to combating climate change would be to help the poor make the necessary energy transition, a role that can combine renewables and fossil fuels.Australian diplomatic sources argue we can help developing countries transition to lower emissions through our expertise.

There is a recognition that not only does Australia have the purest, lowest-emissions coal, but its transport and software infrastructure co-ordinating fossil fuel extraction is world leading in its efficiency.On the one hand, the potential effects of climate change such as floods, droughts and soil erosion will disproportionately hurt the poor.

This is especially true in sub-Saharan Africa.But the best way for the poor to adapt to climate change is to overcome poverty.This is a clear finding from a research report by economists Alexander Golub and Elena Strukova Golub, commissioned by the Bangladesh government.Bangladesh, the country of my birth, is one of the countries most vulnerable to climate change.

The economists find that there are a variety of solutions that may mitigate the effects of climate change, including mangrove protection, early-warning systems and the building of polders - tracts of land protected by dykes.But they are all trumped by the country becoming more wealthy.
The roads, schools, housing and reliable power needed for this to occur cannot be built using green energy alone.
"Energy transition not only includes substituting fossil fuels with non-fossil fuels.

Facilitating low-carbon use of fossil fuels is also an important element," says Sang Shuxun of the Low Carbon Energy Institute at the China University of Mining and Technology.Natural gas is a critical component, too, another area where Australia is world leading in supplies, extraction and distribution.The Energy for Growth Hub, an international research network, estimates that if the countries of Africa tripled their electricity consumption overnight through the use of natural gas, the resulting carbon emissions would be less than 1 per cent of the global total.

Africa accounts for almost a fifth of the world's population but less than 4 per cent of its carbon emissions.Natural gas is plentiful in countries such as Nigeria, Mozambique and Angola.In parallel, it is appropriate we aggressively promote partnerships in renewable energy, such as the low-emissions technology deal struck by India and Australia, a big part of which is alow-cost solar program.
Fortescue has also been engaged by India's Jindal Steel for green hydrogen production.But this can't hide the growing divide between the world's rich and poor over climate policy.

Xi Jinping's absence from Glasgow will bear powerful testimony to this fact.Policymakers in rich countries such as Australia must consider poverty reduction in parallel with mitigating the effects of climate change.

Focusing on our own net zero plan will play a bit part compared with applying our considerable expertise in helping developing countries transition.Blanket bans on fossil fuels will only increase the impact of rising temperatures on the poor by limiting their ability to adapt.If only such concerns played a bigger role in the acceptable opinions of polite society.Tanveer Ahmed is a practising psychiatrist and author.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly uncertain about this document. The writing style and content are not particularly AI-like.
